Summary: Shahidul Islam, a resident of Madarinagar village in Mymensingh, was shot during clashes between protesters and police near Jatrabari Police Station in Dhaka amid unrest tied to the anti-discrimination student movement. He sustained bullet injuries to the abdomen and thigh, reportedly from police fire, and was later pronounced dead at Mugda Medical College Hospital.

Abdullah Al Mahin, a 16-year-old student from Purahitpara, Mymensingh, was fatally shot on August 4, 2024, near the RAJUK Commercial Complex in Uttara, Dhaka, during student-led protests. He was rushed to the National Institute of Neurosciences and Hospital, where he succumbed to his injuries later that night. His body was buried the following morning at Bhutikashar Graveyard in Mymensingh without a post-mortem examination. On November 13, 2024, under a court directive, his body was exhumed for further investigation into a murder case filed by his father, Jamil Hossain.

Incident Location: Near Uttara East Police Station, Azampur, Dhaka
Summary: Nazmul Islam Raju, a 39-year-old tailor from Sehra Munshibari, Mymensingh, was fatally shot on August 5, 2024, near Uttara East Police Station in Azampur, Dhaka. He was injured while participating in a celebratory procession following the resignation of the Sheikh Hasina government. He was taken to Kuwait Maitri Hospital, where he was pronounced dead. His body was transported to his village that same night and buried the following day at Kalibari Graveyard in Mymensingh without a post-mortem examination. On November 13, 2024, following a court order, his body was exhumed for a forensic autopsy as part of a murder investigation initiated by his brother, Rezaul Islam.

Incident Location: In front of Uttara East Police Station, Dhaka
Summary: Abdul Kadir Manik, a 43-year-old sales worker, was shot and killed on 5 August during a victory rally in front of Uttara East Police Station, Dhaka. According to the report, part of his head was severely injured by gunfire. Manik’s family has demanded justice for his killing. His body was brought back to his village the following morning and buried in the family graveyard. Local authorities and community members have since visited the family to gather information about the incident. Manik’s mother and wife continue to call for an official investigation and support from the government.

Abdullah Bin Jahid, an 11th-grade student at Shaheed Ramiz Uddin Cantonment College, was killed by gunfire from law enforcement on 5 August during public protests in Uttara, Dhaka. According to the report, he sustained bullet wounds to his neck and back, and one of the bullets could not be removed. His body was taken to his family home in Kishoreganj later that night, where he was buried. The victim’s mother, Fatema Tuz Zohra, soon discovered that her younger son, Mahmudullah Bin Zisan, had been diagnosed with advanced colon cancer. The family has been struggling to cover medical costs while also grieving Abdullah’s death.

Abul Hossain Mizi was fatally shot on 19 July, 2024 in the Sainboard area of Narayanganj. According to initial accounts, he was traveling to Dhaka for work and got off his auto-rickshaw due to a student-led protest blocking the road. Shortly afterward, gunfire broke out, and he was struck in the abdomen by a bullet. Witnesses rushed him to Proactive Medical Center before transferring him to Dhaka Medical College Hospital, where he later died. His mother subsequently filed a murder case in connection with the incident.

Journalist Abu Taher Md. Turab was shot and killed by police on 19 July, 2024 in Sylhet city while covering the anti-discrimination student movement. He served as a staff reporter for the Daily Naya Diganta’s Sylhet Bureau and Daily Jalalabad. Following his death, a foundation stone was laid on 22 December, 2024 to establish a memorial roundabout in his honor at the main road intersection in Beanibazar municipality. Jamaat leader Muhammad Selim Uddin presided over the ceremony, praising Turab’s dedication to truth and humanity.

Azmat Ali, a BNP leader from Nabiganj and a fish trader, was fatally shot by police on 5 August, 2024 during the anti-discrimination student movement in Jatrabari, Dhaka. He died on the spot after being hit by police gunfire while participating in a procession. Azmat's family, including his wife Rabirun Begum and their three children, have been struggling to survive amidst financial hardship and have received no government assistance to date.

Asif Iqbal, a 29-year-old student leader and activist, was fatally shot during the anti-discrimination student movement in Mirpur-10 on July 19, 2024. A graduate of Independent University Bangladesh and a former Business Administration professional, Asif was known for his leadership skills and commitment to societal change, having also played a prominent role in the 2018 road safety protests. Witnesses described the incident as a targeted sniper attack, with a 7.62 mm bullet causing his death due to excessive bleeding. Asif's burial took place on July 20 at his family's graveyard in Magura district, and his legacy lives on with a commemorative square named "Shaheed Asif Chatwar" in Mirpur. His father has filed a case naming 73 individuals, including former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina, demanding justice for his son's killing.

Imtiaz Ahmed Jabir, a 20-year-old BBA student at Southeast University, was shot during the anti-discrimination student movement in Rampura, Dhaka, on 19 July, 2024. He sustained two gunshot wounds in his right leg and was rushed to Mugda Medical College and later transferred to Dhaka Medical College Hospital. Despite receiving multiple surgeries and 17 blood transfusions, Imtiaz succumbed to his injuries on 26 July, 2024, after seven days in the ICU. A native of Jhikargachha, Jashore, Imtiaz had come to Dhaka to fulfill his parents’ dream of a better future.

Farhan Faiyaz Ratul, a student of the 11th grade at Residential Model College, was killed on July 18, 2024, during clashes between police, Awami League activists, and protesters in Dhanmondi 27, Dhaka, amidst the anti-discrimination student movement. He was injured by rubber bullets and succumbed to his injuries at City Hospital in Mohammadpur around 3:30 PM. The clashes erupted in the morning when students gathered to demonstrate for quota reforms and were met with resistance from police and Awami League activists wielding local weapons. The violence led to multiple injuries and significant unrest in the Dhanmondi, Science Lab, and Azimpur areas. Farhan’s death marks a tragic loss in the ongoing movement.

Hafizur Rahman Sumon, a driver, succumbed to injuries on 16 August, 2024, following an attack during the anti-discrimination student movement on 5 August, 2024, in Sher-e-Bangla Nagar, Dhaka. The peaceful rally near Sher-e-Bangla Women’s College was violently disrupted by Awami League members wielding local weapons, resulting in Sumon being critically injured. He was admitted to Shaheed Suhrawardy Medical College Hospital and later transferred to the ICU, where his condition deteriorated. On 9 October, Sumon’s wife, Mosha. Bithi Khatun, filed a case against the perpetrators, including Sher-e-Bangla Nagar Ward-17 Awami League President Mahe Alam.

Ismail Hossain Rabbi, a 17-year-old second-year student at Shariatpur Polytechnic Institute, was fatally shot on 4 August, 2024, during the anti-discrimination movement in Sayedabad, Karatitola, Dhaka. Rabbi had left his home that day despite family pleas to stay back, joining the student-led rally. According to reports, Rabbi was struck by a live bullet fired during clashes and succumbed to his injuries at the scene. His family later faced significant challenges in retrieving his body and obtaining a death certificate, with claims of harassment from authorities.

Incident Location: Palli Bidyut Mor, Gazipur’s Sripur, Dhaka-Mymensingh Highway
Summary: Zakir Hossain, a 33-year-old garment worker, was fatally shot on 5 August, 2024, during a clash between Border Guard Bangladesh (BGB) forces and protesters at Palli Bidyut Mor, Gazipur. He was one of five victims who died from gunshot wounds in the incident. Zakir, the sole breadwinner of his family, left behind his parents, wife, and a five-year-old daughter, Ilma, who struggles to cope with her father’s absence. According to eyewitnesses, Zakir was injured at the scene and succumbed to his wounds while being transported to Mymensingh Medical College Hospital.

Zulfiqar Ahmed, the Organizational Secretary of the Dhaka Metropolitan Branch of the Student Federation, passed away on August 7, 2024, at a hospital in Dhaka. He was a second-year Fine Arts student at the University of Development Alternative (UODA) and an alumnus of the "Amader Pathshala" school for underprivileged children in Mirpur. Zulfiqar was critically injured by gunfire on August 4, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement's non-cooperation campaign in Mirpur 10. The gunfire, allegedly from Chhatra League and Jubo League activists, resulted in his hospitalization at the National Institute of Neurosciences and Hospital in Agargaon.

Karimul Islam, a 20-year-old resident of West Ruhitnashi village in Lakhai Upazila, Habiganj, succumbed to his injuries on September 30, 2024, at Dhaka Medical College Hospital. He was an active participant in the anti-discrimination student movement and a member of Islami Chhatra Andolon. On August 5, 2024, he was shot in the chest, face, and hand during clashes near Jatrabari Police Station in Dhaka. Despite intensive care treatment, his condition deteriorated, and he passed away after nearly two months of hospitalization. His body was sent to his home village for burial after an autopsy. His death adds to the growing toll of casualties from the movement.

Kawsar Mahmud, a 22-year-old second-year Business Administration student at BGC Trust University in Chattogram, succumbed to his injuries on August 25, 2024, while receiving treatment at the Combined Military Hospital (CMH) in Dhaka. He was injured on August 4, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement in the New Market area of Chattogram. Initially treated locally, Kawsar was later transferred to Dhaka for advanced care. A native of Ramganj Upazila, Lakshmipur, his family had been residing in the Agrabad area of Chattogram for many years. Following a funeral in Dhaka, his body was brought to Chattogram for a second funeral and burial at the Mogoltuli Abdur Rahman Matbar Jame Mosque cemetery in Agrabad.

Abdul Mannan, a rickshaw puller from Erulia Bandighi Purbo Para village in Bogura, was fatally shot on August 4, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement protests on the streets of Bogura. His burial occurred without a post-mortem, but his body was exhumed 111 days later, on November 25, following a court order for a forensic investigation at Shaheed Ziaur Rahman Medical College (Shajimec) Hospital. The murder case, filed on September 11 by his son Runa Hamid, implicated 122 individuals, including Sheikh Hasina and Obaidul Quader, and 200-300 unknown persons.

Faisal Ahmed Shanto, a first-year accounting student at Omar Gani MEC College in Chattogram, was fatally shot on July 16, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement. The incident occurred amidst clashes in Muradpur, near GEC Circle, Chattogram, which turned into a battleground for over two hours. While his family believed he had gone out for tutoring, Faisal was reportedly participating in the protests when he was shot. He was rushed to the hospital by fellow protesters but succumbed to his injuries. Faisal was later buried in his family graveyard in Mahishadi village, Babuganj Upazila, Barishal. His grieving parents demand justice for their son’s death.

Julkar Nain, a 17-year-old student from Palashbari JL Model School, was fatally shot during a celebratory rally on 5 August, 2024, in Baipail, Ashulia, Dhaka. Known for his independent and justice-driven mindset, Julkar actively participated in the anti-discrimination student movements despite his family’s disapproval. During the rally, he was struck by a bullet in the chest and was rushed to Ashulia Women and Children Hospital for initial treatment before being transferred to Enam Hospital in Savar, where he was declared dead around 6:30 PM.

Junayed Islam Ratul, a 13-year-old sixth-grade student at Path Public School in Bogura, succumbed to his injuries on September 30, 2024, after more than a month of hospitalization at the National Institute of Neurosciences and Hospital in Dhaka. On August 5, 2024, he was shot by police during a celebratory march following the resignation of Sheikh Hasina as Prime Minister. The incident occurred near Bogura’s Sadar Police Station when police fired indiscriminately at protesters, with shotgun pellets striking Junayed in his head and body. Despite intensive care, Junayed could not recover and passed away. His body was taken to the Central Shaheed Minar for a funeral prayer before being transported to Bogura, where he was buried at Namajgor Anjuman Cemetery after a second funeral.

Incident Location: Rabindra Sarani, 3 No. Sector, Uttara, Dhaka
Summary: Md. Lablu Mia, a 41-year-old resident of Rangpur, was killed on August 5, 2024, during clashes in the anti-discrimination student movement in Uttara, Dhaka. A month later, his cousin, Dhuku Mia, filed a murder case at Uttara East Police Station, accusing 221 individuals, including 210 from Rangpur. The accused include prominent local Awami League leaders and national political figures such as former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. The case alleges that Lablu’s death was orchestrated under their instructions. Legal experts have raised concerns about the validity of such cases, suggesting they may aim to harass rather than deliver justice.

Md. Labu Mia, a 40-year-old rickshaw puller from Dumrai village in Raiganj, Sirajganj, was fatally shot on August 5, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement near Ashulia Police Station, Dhaka. He was the sole breadwinner of his family and had been supporting his wife, Shefali Khatun, with his earnings. On the day of the incident, Labu joined the protests, where police fired on the demonstrators, killing him on the spot. His body was taken for post-mortem examination and buried on August 6 in his village.

Liton Matubbar was killed on July 18 in the capital's Badda during violence over the reform movement. He had been working as a tiler for a long time in a rented house in Badda. Liton's elder brother Bashir Matubbar said that after being shot, Liton was admitted to Kurmitola Hospital in Dhaka. He died while undergoing treatment there. Later, the police took the body to Suhrawardy Medical College Hospital for an autopsy.

Khandaker Mamun, general secretary of Dhamsona Union Sheccha Sebak Dol of Ashulia, died while undergoing treatment during a clash with police during the August 5 anti-discrimination student movement in Savar, Dhaka.

Maruf Hossain (21), a final-year student of Kushtia Polytechnic College, was shot dead in front of his rented house in Banasree, the capital of the quota reform movement, on July 19. Maruf, who had come to Dhaka to do an internship 20 days ago, was staying in a rented house in Banasree with his friends.

On the afternoon of July 19, Md. Masud participated in a peaceful protest along with many students and the public on the road in front of the under-construction building called Paradise Palace in Merajnagar of Kadamtali Police Station. At that time, leaders and activists of various Awami League organizations started attacking and indiscriminately firing on the protesting students and the public. Masud was seriously injured by sharp weapons and a bullet wound to the head. He was admitted to Dhaka Medical College Hospital in a serious condition and died on the night of July 20 while undergoing treatment.

Masum took part in the anti-discrimination student movement on Monday, August 5. During the movement, he was shot in the Mawna area of ​​Gazipur. Later, when the people there took him to Bhaluka Hospital, the hospital's duty doctor declared him dead.

Masum Sheikh (30) of Phulpur was shot dead by police while participating in a victory procession in Uttara, Dhaka, on August 5. He was the son of the late Abdur Razzak of Kokail village in Bowla union of the upazila.

Mehedi was protesting with students protesting against discrimination in the Gazaria area of ​​Munshiganj at 5 pm on July 20. Police and Awami League leaders and activists opened fire on them indiscriminately. Mehedi was shot in the head, and he immediately collapsed to the ground and died.

Muslim Uddin Milon, a worker at a jewelry shop, was fatally shot on 19 July, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement in the City Bazar area of Rangpur. He was struck by gunfire during a clash between police, Awami League members, and student protesters. Milon’s body was buried the following day without an autopsy. However, on 15 September, 58 days after his burial, his body was exhumed under a court order for further investigation and sent to Rangpur Medical College Hospital for autopsy.

Saju Islam, a 26-year-old factory worker from Panchagarh, died on August 11, 2024, after being critically injured during a protest in Mowna, Gazipur, on August 5. A gunshot wound to his abdomen left him fighting for his life at Mymensingh Medical College Hospital. The primary breadwinner for his family, Saju had recently become a father, naming his newborn son after a fellow activist killed earlier in the movement. Despite his aspirations to support his family and provide for his infant, he passed away without seeing his son. His grieving family now faces an uncertain future, mourning the loss of their sole provider.

Incident Location: Near Shah Mokhdum College, Rajshahi, during student protests
Summary: Sakib Anjum, a Computer Science and Engineering (CSE) student from Barendra University, was fatally shot on August 5, 2024, near Shah Mokhdum College in Rajshahi during the anti-discrimination student movement protests. Due to the absence of police and medical personnel at the time, his body was buried without an autopsy. Following a court order, his body was exhumed 72 days later, on October 16, 2024, for a forensic investigation at Rajshahi Medical College Hospital. The investigation stems from a murder case filed by his father, Mainul Haque, against 342 individuals, including prominent Awami League figures such as A.H.M.

Incident Location: Rampura Ekramunnesa Degree College, 337, 1 TV Rd, Dhaka 1212

Summary: Arafat Rahman Akash, a 16-year-old from Sonaiamuri, Noakhali, was fatally shot on 21 July, 2024, at Chittagong Road, Dhaka, during a brief lift in curfew. Akash had moved to Dhaka six months prior to assist his father, a fruit vendor, in their family business. While heading to a hotel for breakfast with his father, gunfire erupted, and Akash was struck by three bullets. Despite attempts to admit him to two local private hospitals, he was denied treatment and succumbed to his injuries in an ambulance en route to Dhaka Medical College Hospital.

Irfan Bhuiyan, a 21-year-old student at United International University (UIU), was fatally shot on July 18, 2024, during clashes between protesters and police in Jatrabari, Dhaka, as part of the anti-discrimination student movement. The incident occurred near Shanir Akhra Road, where police reportedly opened fire indiscriminately during the protests. Irfan's body was transported to National Hospital in Old Dhaka, where he was declared dead. His tragic death highlights the severe toll of the movement, which aimed to challenge systemic inequalities. Irfan's university later commemorated him through a dedicated space preserving the movement's history and legacy.

Jamal Hossain Sikder, a 40-year-old painter from Gournadi, Barisal, was fatally shot on 20 July, 2024, at Chittagong Road, Dhaka, during violence linked to the quota reform movement. Jamal had recently relocated to Dhaka with his wife and daughter to prepare for migration to Saudi Arabia, hoping to improve his family’s financial condition and secure his daughter’s education. He was struck by gunfire while shopping for travel essentials with his brother-in-law, just days before his scheduled departure.

Incident Location: Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman's residence garden, Dhanmondi 32, Dhaka
Summary: Kamal Hossain, a 36-year-old hotel cook and part-time rickshaw driver from Khuliarchar village, Ishwarganj, Mymensingh, was found dead on August 6, 2024, in the garden of Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujibur Rahman's residence at Dhanmondi 32, Dhaka. His charred body was identified by his burnt clothing, which bore his name, and his mobile phone, which was intact but had its SIM card removed. Kamal left his home on August 5, stating his intention to join the anti-discrimination student movement, despite protests from his wife and in-laws. He did not return, and the next day, his family received news of his death.

Masud Parvez Bhuiyan, an Inspector of the Police Bureau of Investigation (PBI) in Narayanganj, was brutally attacked on 19 July, 2024, in Banasree, Dhaka, amidst unrest linked to the quota reform movement. He was assaulted while returning from a pharmacy in civilian clothing and was later found critically injured near Farazi Hospital. Masud succumbed to his injuries on 21 July, 2024, at Rajarbagh Police Line Hospital. His body was initially buried without autopsy but was exhumed on 30 July for further investigation. Masud left behind a grieving wife, Marina Akhtar Bina, and three children, who have pleaded for justice, urging authorities to identify and prosecute those responsible for his murder.

Minhazul Islam, a garment worker from Uttar Ramshala village in Akkelpur Upazila, Joypurhat, was fatally shot during the anti-discrimination student movement in the Joy Bangla Road area of Gazipur. Following his death, his body was transported to his hometown and buried without a post-mortem examination. On September 27, 2024, his uncle, Abdul Quddus, filed a case with Gazipur's Gacha Police Station against 196 individuals, including former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina. Subsequently, on October 1, the Gazipur Metropolitan Chief Judicial Court ordered the exhumation of Minhazul's body for autopsy to determine the exact cause of death. On December 1, 2024, in the presence of officials, his body was exhumed and sent to the Forensic Department of Rajshahi Medical College Hospital for examination.

Incident Location: Mayor Hanif Flyover Toll Plaza, Kazla end, Dhaka

Summary: Selim Talukder, a 32-year-old graduate from BGMEA University of Fashion and Technology and a garment factory worker, was fatally injured by police firing during the anti-discrimination student movement near BRAC University on July 18, 2024. Despite being shot with 18 pellets in the head and 57 in the chest and back, he succumbed to his injuries after 14 days in the ICU at Popular Hospital, Dhaka. Selim's father, Sultan Talukder, and his grieving parents demand recognition of their son as a martyr and justice for his untimely death. Despite administrative hurdles and harassment, Selim's family brought his body home without an autopsy.

Shamim Hawlader was fatally shot on July 20, 2024, during a rally in support of the anti-discrimination student movement at Prashika Mor, Rupnagar, Dhaka. According to the case filed by his cousin, Samrat Hawlader, thousands of protesters were participating in the movement when members of ruling party affiliates opened fire indiscriminately, striking Shamim in the chest. He was rushed to Shaheed Suhrawardy Medical College Hospital, where he was pronounced dead.

Md. Shohan Shah, a 27-year-old mechanical engineer at a garment factory in Rampura, Dhaka, succumbed to his injuries on July 23, 2024, while receiving treatment at the Combined Military Hospital (CMH). He was injured on July 19, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement in the Rampura CNG pump area, where police reportedly fired live ammunition, striking him in the left side of his back. Shohan was initially treated at a chest disease hospital before being transferred to CMH. A member of the BNP, Shohan was the eldest son of farmer Shah Sekendar from Chandikhali village, Shreepur Upazila, Magura.

Incident Location: Science Lab, New Elephant Rd, Dhaka

Summary: Tariqul Islam Rubel, a worker at Rakeen City in Mirpur-13, Dhaka, was fatally shot on 19 July, 2024, during a clash between police and protesters amidst the anti-discrimination student movement. Rubel was on his way home when he sought cover behind a vehicle during the unrest but was fatally struck by a bullet in the head when he attempted to assess the situation. The bullet caused severe injuries, resulting in his death on the spot. Rubel’s body was transported to his family’s village in Tairail, Kishoreganj, where he was buried the following day.

Mirajul Islam Khan, a 21-year-old resident of Mahishkhocha Baroghoria village in Lalmonirhat, was fatally injured on August 5, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement in Jatrabari, Dhaka. Employed at a mobile phone shop due to financial hardship, Mirajul joined a protest rally at the Dhaka-Chattogram highway underpass near Jatrabari fish market, where he was shot. Initially taken to Delta Medical College by bystanders, he was later transferred to Dhaka Medical College Hospital and eventually to Rangpur Medical College Hospital due to the severity of his condition. A bullet was surgically removed, but despite intensive care, he succumbed to his injuries on August 8, 2024.

Incident Location: Baitul Atiq Jame Mosque Road, Rampura
Near Savar Model Mosque, Savar, Dhaka
Summary: Nafisa Hossain Marwa, a 17-year-old science student at Sahazuddin Sarkar Ideal High School in Tongi, was fatally shot on August 5, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement near Savar Model Mosque, Dhaka. Despite her uncle's disapproval, Nafisa joined the protests, where she was struck by a bullet and taken to LabZone Hospital for treatment but succumbed to her injuries shortly after. She had recently passed her HSC examinations with a GPA of 4.25, bringing pride to her family. Her mother, Kulsum Begum, who was working abroad for her daughters' future, was devastated by the loss of Nafisa, who aspired to become a graphic designer and photographer. Nafisa was buried in Tongi at her father’s residence, as per his decision, after a funeral in Savar.

Riya Gope, a 6-year-old girl from Nayamati, Narayanganj, was fatally injured on July 19, 2024, during clashes in her neighborhood related to the anti-discrimination student movement. While playing on the roof of her family's four-story building, Riya was struck by a bullet in the back of her head as her father, Dipak Kumar Gope, tried to bring her inside to safety. She was rushed to a local hospital and later transferred to Dhaka Medical College Hospital, where she underwent surgery. Despite the efforts of the doctors and prayers of her community, Riya succumbed to her injuries on July 24, 2024. Her death devastated her parents and the neighborhood, where she was cherished as the center of her family’s world.

Sad Al Afnan, an HSC science student from Victory College in Lakshmipur, was fatally shot on August 4, 2024, during clashes related to the anti-discrimination student movement in Lakshmipur town. The incident occurred amidst a violent confrontation where former Upazila Chairman Salah Uddin and his associates reportedly opened fire on students, turning the town into a battleground. Afnan, the son of the late Saleh Ahmed, had recently passed his HSC exams with a GPA of 4.17. He was buried the same day at his maternal uncle’s residence. His mother, Nasima Akter, devastated by the loss of her son just two months after her husband’s death, expressed her grief, lamenting the loss of her dreams for Afnan’s future.

Saffwan Akhter Sadya, a 15-year-old 10th-grade student from Savar Cantonment School, was shot dead during a victory rally on August 5, 2024. Leaving a devastated family behind, Sadya joined the rally from his study table, unaware of the impending tragedy. Police fired indiscriminately to clear the streets, and a bullet pierced his right chest, killing him instantly. His family buried him in their ancestral graveyard in Jamalpur on August 6.

Saiful Islam, a 21-year-old tenth-grade student from Kaushalya, Sindurpur Union, Daganbhuiyan Upazila, Feni, was shot on August 4, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement in the CRB area of Chattogram. Visiting his uncle's house at the time, he participated in the protest and was assaulted and shot, reportedly by members of the Awami League, sustaining injuries to his head and body. He was initially treated at Chattogram Medical College Hospital for over a month before being transferred to Dhaka's Combined Military Hospital. Despite extensive medical care, Saiful succumbed to his injuries on September 30, 2024. His death underscores the severe consequences faced by participants in the movement.

Sohag Mia, a 15-year-old boy from Barkhapan village, Kalmakanda, Netrokona, was fatally shot on July 19, 2024, in Noyabazar, Dhaka, during the anti-discrimination student movement. He had stepped out of his home after Asr prayers when he was hit by gunfire. Locals rushed him to the hospital, but he succumbed to his injuries. Given the volatile situation at the time, his father, Md. Shafayet Mia, brought the body back to their family graveyard and buried it without an autopsy. On August 20, 2024, Shafayet Mia filed a murder case naming former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina as the principal accused alongside 91 others and 200-300 unnamed individuals.

Roman Mia, a 10th-grade student of Nab Kisholoy High School, was killed on 5 August, 2024 during a celebratory rally in Chanpara, Rupganj. According to a case filed by his aunt, Reena, Awami League leaders and activists attacked the rally with firearms and explosives, leading to multiple injuries. Roman was shot during the assault and later declared dead at Puragram Hospital. On 21 August, a murder case was filed against 105 individuals, including former Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina and other high-ranking leaders, accusing them of orchestrating the attack.

Omar Faruk, a 16-year-old resident of Nurabad Union, Char Fasson Upazila, Bhola, was fatally shot on August 4, 2024, under the Allah Karim Mosque foot overbridge in Mohammadpur, Dhaka, while returning home from work during the anti-discrimination student movement. His family transported his body to their village, where he was buried on August 6 without a post-mortem examination. On September 29, following a court order, his body was exhumed for an autopsy as part of a murder investigation initiated by his father, Milon Farazi, naming 58 individuals as suspects.

Incident Location: 200 metres off the Mirpur Model Police Station

Summary: Sazzad Hossain Sajal, a first-year textile engineering student at City University in Ashulia, was fatally shot during the anti-discrimination student movement on August 5, 2024. He was killed by police gunfire during protests and his body was reportedly burned to conceal the evidence. Sajal had called his mother shortly before his death, expressing his resolve and preparing her for the possibility of martyrdom. His family, originally from Shyampur village, Saghata Upazila, Gaibandha, identified his charred remains two days later using his university ID card. The military later handed over his body with state honors, and he was buried in his village on August 7, 2024. His tragic death devastated his family, shattering their dreams of seeing him become an engineer.

Tamim Shikder, a 10-year-old third-grade student from Rampura Primary School in Dhaka, was fatally shot on July 19, 2024, during clashes between police and protesters involved in the anti-discrimination student movement in Rampura. While playing football with friends, he stood near the road to observe the ongoing confrontation and was struck by a bullet in the chest. He was rushed to Dhaka Medical College Hospital, but he succumbed to his injuries shortly after arrival. Tamim was the only son of rickshaw puller Jewel Shikder, originally from Khapura village, Bhanga Upazila, Faridpur. Due to financial constraints, Tamim’s burial took place the same night at Rampura Cemetery. His tragic death has left his family devastated.

Mohammad Hasan, a 30-year-old laborer from Raishat village in Lalmohan Upazila, Bhola, was shot during clashes at Jatrabari Intersection, Dhaka, on August 5, 2024, amid the quota reform and subsequent anti-government protests. Employed at a wholesale vegetable market in Jatrabari, he was critically injured and admitted to the Intensive Care Unit of the Burn Unit at Dhaka Medical College Hospital. After battling for his life, Hasan succumbed to his injuries on August 24, 2024. His father, rickshaw puller Kabir Hossain, confirmed the incident, stating that Hasan resided in the Kajla area of Jatrabari with his wife and two children. Hasan's body was sent to the hospital morgue for autopsy.

Imran Hasan, a resident of Meghna Industrial Area, Narayanganj, was fatally shot on August 5, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement in Jatrabari, Dhaka. He joined the protests with his friends without informing his family and was killed on the spot by police gunfire at the protest site. Imran was the elder son of local shopkeeper Md. Saleh Ahmed, and his grieving mother, Kohinur Akter, continues to demand justice. Local authorities, including the Union Parishad member and upazila officials, acknowledged the incident but stated they had not yet received any formal complaint or taken specific action regarding the case.

Abdullah, a 23-year-old political science student at Government Shaheed Suhrawardy College in Old Dhaka, was fatally injured during the anti-discrimination movement. On August 5, 2024, he was shot in the forehead near Bangshal Police Station, where he reportedly lay on the road for 2-3 hours before being rescued and taken to Mitford Hospital and later to Dhaka Medical College Hospital for surgery. After initial treatment, he returned home to Benapole, Jessore, but later experienced severe complications, prompting his transfer back to Dhaka Medical College Hospital and eventually to CMH on August 22. Abdullah succumbed to his injuries on November 14, 2024, at CMH, Dhaka. His body was sent to Shaheed Suhrawardy Medical College morgue for autopsy.

Badiuzzaman, a garment worker from Majhpara village in Kaunia Upazila, Rangpur, was killed on August 5, 2024, during clashes at Chashara, Narayanganj, as part of the anti-discrimination student movement. He resided with his wife and child in Hajiganj, Narayanganj. According to the case filed by his wife, Aduri Khatun, Awami League activists attacked and assaulted him and his cousin, Swadhin Mia, with sticks and weapons under the instructions of senior political leaders. Badiuzzaman succumbed to his injuries after being taken to Narayanganj General Hospital. Following pressure from the accused, the family transported his body to their village without a post-mortem examination and buried him there. A case has been filed against 36 named individuals, including Sheikh Hasina, Obaidul Quader, and Shamim Osman, and 150 unknown persons, accusing them of orchestrating his murder.

Md. Dulal Sardar was killed on July 18, 2024, while participating in a peaceful demonstration on BRAC University Road, Badda, Dhaka, during the anti-discrimination student movement. Around 10:00 AM, supporters of various Awami League-affiliated organizations opened fire on the protesters, fatally striking Dulal in the chest. He died on the spot. On October 2, 2024, a murder case was filed at Badda Police Station by Shariful Islam, accusing Awami League leaders and activists of orchestrating the attack. Following the investigation, police arrested Akram Khan, the joint secretary of the Krishak League in Badda’s Ward 37, on November 7, 2024.

Incident Location: Former mayor Jamil Hossain’s house, Hakimpur, Dinajpur
Summary: Asaduzzaman Noor, a 17-year-old student from Borodangapara village, Hakimpur Upazila, Dinajpur, was killed on August 5, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement. Allegedly abducted and tortured alongside others at the residence of former mayor Jamil Hossain, Asaduzzaman and another victim, Naim Hossain, died as a result of severe physical abuse. Their bodies were later burned to conceal evidence during an arson attack at the house. The remains were recovered by the fire service and initially buried without an autopsy on August 6, 2024. On September 25, following a court order, Asaduzzaman's body was exhumed for forensic examination to assist in the murder investigation. The case includes allegations against former MP Shibli Sadik and 23 others, along with 90-100 unnamed suspects.

Ekramul Haque Sajid, a student of the 14th batch in the Accounting and Information Systems department at Jagannath University, succumbed to his injuries on August 14, 2024, at the Combined Military Hospital (CMH) in Dhaka. He was critically injured on August 4, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement in Mirpur, Dhaka, when a police bullet struck the back of his head. Sajid had been receiving treatment at CMH since the incident but did not recover. His passing was confirmed by university faculty members, and he was laid to rest in his hometown of Tangail. His death has left the Jagannath University community in mourning.

Sheikh Shahriar Bin Matin, an HSC student from Ishwarganj Ideal College, was fatally shot on July 18, 2024, near Mirpur-10 Circle, Dhaka, during the anti-discrimination student movement. A bullet entered through his right eye and exited through his head, critically wounding him. He passed away on July 20, 2024, while undergoing treatment. Shahriar had completed five HSC exams before the movement disrupted the schedule, and his remaining results were assessed based on subject mapping. He passed with a GPA of 4.83, a result that his grieving parents, who were performing Hajj in Saudi Arabia, received with mixed emotions. Shahriar aspired to become a successful businessman but tragically lost his life in the protests.

Ashiqur Rahman Ashiq, a 24-year-old second-year undergraduate student at Panchpir Degree College in Kurigram, succumbed to his injuries on August 25, 2024, at Bangabandhu Sheikh Mujib Medical University in Dhaka. He was injured on August 4, 2024, during clashes between Awami League-affiliated groups and students at Shapla Chattar, Kurigram, when he was struck on the head with a stone. Initially treated at Rangpur Medical College Hospital, he was later transferred to Dhaka for advanced care due to severe bleeding in his brain. Despite efforts, Ashiq could not be saved. His younger brother, Atikur Rahman, confirmed that they participated in the protest as non-political students. Following his death, a funeral was held at the Central Shaheed Minar, and he was buried in his village in Satbhita, Buraburi Union, Kurigram, on August 26, 2024.

Ramzan Mia Jibon, a 26-year-old worker at a shoe factory in Alubazar, Old Dhaka, succumbed to his injuries on August 7, 2024, at Dhaka Medical College Hospital. He was critically injured on August 5, 2024, during clashes near the Awami League office in Gulistan, Dhaka, as part of the anti-discrimination student movement. Ramzan sustained severe head injuries and was unconscious throughout his treatment in the ICU. His family, residing in Mirpur, was informed about his condition through his phone on the day of the incident. He is survived by his wife, Sahara Khatun, who is five months pregnant, and his family in his ancestral home in Bajitpur, Kishoreganj. His body is currently held at Dhaka Medical College morgue for post-mortem examination.

Rakib Bepari, a 21-year-old garment worker from Fatullah, Narayanganj, was fatally shot on July 21, 2024, during clashes between protesters and police in the Post Office area of Fatullah as part of the anti-discrimination student movement. He was caught in the crossfire while out shopping and was later pronounced dead at Khanpur Hospital. Rakib, who was the primary breadwinner for his family, lived in a rented house near his workplace with his parents, disabled elder brother, and newlywed wife, Jannatul Akhtar. His body was transported to his ancestral village in Jamaddwip, Banaripara, Barishal, and buried the following morning without an autopsy. On December 5, 2024, his body was exhumed for forensic examination to confirm the cause of death as part of the ongoing investigation.

Md. Iman, a 17-year-old worker at a food stall in Gulshan, Dhaka, succumbed to his injuries on August 3, 2024, at Dhaka Medical College Hospital. He was injured on July 19, 2024, during clashes related to the anti-discrimination student movement while commuting from his home in Bhatara to Gulshan. A bullet entered and exited through the right side of his abdomen, critically wounding him. Originally from Muradnagar, Cumilla, Iman lived with his sister, Tahmina Begum, in Dhaka. Despite 15 days of intensive care, Iman could not recover. His death adds to the growing toll of fatalities associated with the student movement, bringing the total to 216.

Nasima Akter, a 24-year-old woman from Noakhali, succumbed to her injuries on July 20, 2024, after being shot during the anti-discrimination student movement in Dhanmondi 1, Dhaka. On July 19, 2024, she was visiting her brother’s home and went to the rooftop with her nephews and others to watch the commotion below when gunfire erupted. A bullet pierced the chest of her nephew, Ayman Uddin, before striking Nasima in the face, causing critical injuries. Nasima was taken to a private hospital, where she passed away the following day. Ayman survived after 15 days of treatment. Nasima, the youngest of seven siblings, was buried in her maternal grandparents’ home in Rajganj Union, Begumganj, Noakhali.

Liza Akter, a 19-year-old domestic worker from Deula village in Borhanuddin Upazila, Bhola, was fatally shot on July 18, 2024, during the anti-discrimination student movement in Shantinagar, Dhaka. While standing on the balcony of the seventh floor of her employer's residence, she was struck by a bullet in her abdomen. She was initially treated at Aurora Specialized Hospital before being transferred to Popular Medical College Hospital. Despite receiving medical care, she succumbed to her injuries on July 22, 2024. Liza’s body was taken to her home village, where she was buried in the family graveyard.

Incident Location: Dhamrai Hardinge Government School and College gate, Dhaka
Summary: Afiqul Islam Sad, an 18-year-old student of Hardinge Government College, was fatally injured during the anti-discrimination student movement in Dhaka’s Dhamrai area. On August 5, 2024, Sad was shot in the head during an indiscriminate firing incident near the college gate. He was immediately rushed to Enam Medical College Hospital in Savar, where he succumbed to his injuries on August 8, 2024. On August 21, 2024, Sad’s grandfather, Azim Uddin, filed a murder case accusing 82 individuals, including prominent local leaders such as former MP Benazir Ahmed and members of the Awami League and its affiliate organizations. The first arrest in the case was made on November 20, 2024, when police detained Faruq Hossain, 50, a former joint general secretary of Dhamrai Upazila Jubo League.

Shahriyar Khan Anas, a 16-year-old 10th-grade student, was shot dead during the anti-discrimination student movement in Dhaka’s Chankharpul area on August 5, 2024. A bullet pierced his chest, killing him shortly after he joined the protests against his parents' wishes, leaving behind a letter explaining his decision to participate. His family discovered his body at Mitford Hospital's morgue after receiving a call from an anonymous individual. Anas was buried on August 6 in Jurain Cemetery following a local funeral procession, but his family has since struggled to receive official documentation for his death. Despite his sacrifice, neither state support nor justice has been extended to his grieving family.

Abdul Motalib, a student participating in the peaceful one-point anti-discrimination movement for government reform, was fatally shot on August 4, 2024, at Jigatola Bus Stand in Hazaribagh, Dhaka, during an attack by Awami League-affiliated groups. Following an investigation, Hazaribagh police arrested Maruf Hossain, a prominent Awami League financier and former president of the New Super Market Shop Owners Association, and Mahbub Hossain Sanjay, an active member of the armed “Helmet Force” linked to the attack. The arrests were based on CCTV footage, intelligence, and technological analysis.

Farid Sheikh, a 30-year-old fruit wholesaler and former student political activist, was fatally injured on August 4, 2024, during anti-discrimination student protests in Jatrabari, Dhaka. Despite family warnings, Farid participated in protests while working at his cousin's shop. He was shot in the abdomen and, after being denied treatment at several hospitals, succumbed to his injuries at Mugda Hospital on August 6.
